        - (b) of services within seven days after the date of the conclusion of the agreement,

without reason and without penalty.

(2) The only charge that may be levied on the consumer is the direct cost of returning the goods.

(3) This  section  shall  not  be  construed  to  limit  the  rights  of  a consumer provided for in any other law.

      - This section does not apply to an electronic transaction

        - (a) for  financial  services,  including  but  not  limited  to,  investment services, insurance and reinsurance operations, banking services and operations relating to dealings in securities;

        - (b) by way of an auction;

        - (c) for the supply of foodstuffs, beverages or other goods intended for  everyday  consumption  supplied  to  the  home,  residence  or workplace of the consumer;

        - (d) for services which began with the consumer's consent before the end of the seven-day grace period;

        - (e) where the price for the supply of goods or services is dependent on  fluctuations  in  the  financial  markets  and  which  cannot  be controlled by the supplier;

        - (f) where the goods

            - (i) are made to the consumer's specification,

            - (ii) by reason of their nature cannot be returned, or

            - (iii) are perishable;

        - (g) where  audio  or  video  recordings  or  computer  software  were unsealed by the consumer;

        - (h) for the sale of newspapers, periodicals, magazines and books;

        - (i) for the provision of gaming and lottery services; or

        - (j) for the provision of accommodation, transport, catering or leisure services  where  the  supplier  has  commenced  the  provision  of these services on a specific date or within a specific period.

49. (1) Except in the case of a notice sent by an electronic communications provider  to  a  customer  in  relation  to  the  service,  a  person  shall  not  send unsolicited  electronic  communications  to  a  consumer  without  obtaining  the prior consent of the consumer.

(2) A person who sends electronic commercial communication to a consumer shall provide the consumer

        - (a) with the option to cancel the subscription to the mailing list of that person, and

        - (b) with  the  identifying  particulars  of  the  source  from  which  that person  obtained  the  consumer's  personal  information  at  the request of the consumer.

(3) An  agreement  shall  not  be  deemed  to  have  been  concluded where a consumer fails to respond to an unsolicited communication; and the consumer is entitled to recover the costs associated with  the cancellation of unsolicited communication.

(4) A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than five thousand penalty  units or a term of imprisonment of not more than ten years or to both.

(5) A person who sends unsolicited commercial communications to another person or who continues to send unsolicited commercial communications after cancellation of the subscription commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than five thousand penalty units or a term of imprisonment of not more than ten years or to both.

provisions.title: Liability for misuse of electronic payment medium
provisions.plainLanguage: This section clarifies when a user of an electronic payment method is responsible for unauthorized charges. Generally, users are not liable if someone else misuses their payment method without their involvement. However, liability may apply if the payment method was lost or stolen and used before the issuer was notified, or if the user allowed someone else to use it. The issuer must provide contact information for reporting lost or stolen payment methods.
provisions.rawText:
50. (1) A holder of an electronic payment medium shall not, unless acting in collusion with another person, be liable to the issuer for loss arising from use of the medium by a person who is not acting or being treated as acting as the agent of the holder.

      - Subsection (1) does not prevent

        - (a) the holder of the electronic payment medium from being made liable  for loss to the issuer arising  from use of the  medium  by another  person  during  a  period  beginning  when  the  medium ceases to be in the possession of an authorised person and ending

        - (b) the holder from being made liable to any extent for loss to the issuer  from  use  of  the  medium  by  a  person  who  acquired possession of it with the holder's consent.

- Subsections  (2)  does  not  apply  to  the  use  of  the  electronic payment medium after the issuer has been given  notice of loss and does not apply unless the issuer provides the holder with particulars of the name, address and telephone number of a person stated to be the person to whom notice is to be given.

- The  notice  takes  effect  when  received,  but  where  it  is  given orally, shall be confirmed in writing within fourteen clear days.

- A sum paid by the holder for the issue of the electronic payment medium is treated as paid towards satisfaction of liability under this section to the extent that it has not been previously offset by use made of the medium.

- The  holder  or  a  person  authorised  by  the  holder  to  use  the electronic  payment  medium  is  an  authorised  person  for  the  purpose  of subsection (2).

provisions.title: Electronic payment medium lists prohibited
provisions.plainLanguage: This law prevents banks from sharing lists of customers' electronic payment information (like card numbers and addresses) without their permission or a court order. Banks can share credit ratings with other banks if they notify the customer within a week. Banks and their leadership can face fines or jail time for breaking this law.
provisions.rawText:
- (1) A financial institution shall not

- (a) make available;

- (b) lend; or

        - (c) sell any list or portion of a list of holders of an electronic payment medium and their addresses and account numbers to any person without the prior written consent of the holders except by order of a Court.

- A financial institution may make available to another financial institution  information  about  an  electronic  payment  medium  holder's  credit rating  without  the  holder's  prior  written  consent  if  written  notice  of  the disclosure is given to the holder within seven days subject to any law regulating credit rating institutions.

- A financial institution which contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and each director and officer of the institution who fails to ensure compliance with this Act is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than two thousand five hundred penalty units or imprisonment for a term of not more than five years or to both.

provisions.title: Non-exclusion
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision ensures that consumer rights outlined in the Act cannot be taken away by any agreement. If an agreement attempts to exclude these rights, that part of the agreement is legally void. This protects consumers by guaranteeing they always receive the rights and protections provided by the Act.
provisions.rawText:
- A provision in an agreement which excludes consumer rights provided for in this Act is void.

## Protected computers and critical database

provisions.title: Protected computer
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows the Minister to designate computer systems as "protected," especially those related to national security, essential services, or government operations. Certain systems are automatically considered protected based on their function. Gaining unauthorized access to a protected system is a criminal offense that can result in fines and/or imprisonment.

provisions.title: Identification of critical electronic record and critical databases
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows the Minister to designate certain electronic records as critical if they relate to national security or citizen well-being. It also enables the Minister to create a process for identifying databases that are critical. These designations and procedures will be formally announced in the Gazette.
provisions.rawText:
55. The Minister may by notice in the Gazette

        - (a) declare certain classes of information which are of importance to the  protection  of  the  national  security  of  the  Republic  or  the economic  and  social  well-being  of  its  citizens  to  be  critical electronic records for the purpose of this Act; and

        - (b) establish  a  procedure  to  be  followed  in  the  identification  of critical databases for the purposes of this Act.

provisions.title: Scope of critical database protection
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows the Minister to classify certain electronic information as "critical" if it concerns national security, the economy, or public well-being. This classification subjects the information to specific regulations outlined in sections 56 to 60 of the law. The designation empowers the Minister to protect sensitive electronic data deemed vital to the country's interests.
provisions.rawText: 56. The  Minister  may  declare  certain  classes  of  information  relating  to national security or the economic or social wellbeing of the public to be critical electronic record for the purposes of sections 56 to 60.

provisions.title: Registration of critical databases
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows the Minister to set up a registration system for critical databases. The requirements and procedures for registration will be made public. Registering a database involves providing information about who manages it, where it's located, and what kind of information it holds.
provisions.rawText:
57. (1) The Minister may by notice in the Gazette determine

        - (a) requirements for the registration of a critical database;

        - (b) procedures for the registration of a critical database; and

        - (c) any other matter relating to registration.

(2)  Registration  of  a  critical  database  means  recording  the  following information

        - (a) the full name, address and contact details of the critical database administrator;

        - (b) the location of the critical database, including the locations of the component parts where a critical database is not stored at a single location; and

        - (c) a  general  description  of  the  categories  or types  of  information stored in the critical database.

provisions.title: Management of critical databases
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision tasks the Minister with establishing minimum standards for the management and protection of critical databases. These standards will address areas like access, security, and data integrity. The goal is to ensure these databases are adequately protected and managed. This law does not prevent public bodies from performing their duties as defined by other laws.

provisions.title: Restrictions on disclosure of information
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision restricts who can access information in the registry of critical databases, generally limiting it to Agency employees. The Agency can share information with law enforcement and other government bodies. The Agency retains the right to argue against disclosing information in court if it could harm national security or public interests.
provisions.rawText:
59. (1) Information contained in the register of a critical database shall not be disclosed to another person other than to employees of the Agency who are responsible for the keeping of the register.

          - The Agency is at liberty to disclose information to

        - (a) a law enforcement agency; and

        - (b) a Ministry, Department or Agency.

(3) Nothing in this law shall preclude the Agency from pleading in proceedings  relating  to  information  held  in  its  custody  or  records  that production or disclosure of a matter may be prejudicial to the security of the State or injurious to the public  interest in accordance with article 135 of Constitution.

provisions.title: Audits
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows the Minister to order audits to ensure the Act is being followed. The audits are to be conducted by the critical database administrator. The National Information Technology Authority is designated as the administrator responsible for overseeing the country's ICT infrastructure and electronic records.
provisions.rawText:
60. (1) The  Minister  may  direct  that  audits  be  conducted  by  the  critical database administrator to assess compliance with the provisions of this Act.

(2) For the purposes of subsection (1), the National Information Technology Authority shall act as the critical electronic records and database administrator responsible for overseeing ICT infrastructure of the Republic.

provisions.title: Non-compliance with Act
provisions.plainLanguage: If an audit finds non-compliance, the Minister reviews the report and sends recommendations to the National Security Council. The Council can then take necessary actions to protect national security. The National Information Technology Authority provides advice to the Minister regarding ICT infrastructure audits.
provisions.rawText:
61. (1) The Minister on receipt of the audit report shall consider,

        - (a) any action recommended to remedy the non-compliance; and

        - (b) the period within which the remedial action shall be performed.

(3) The National Information Technology Authority shall advise the Minister  on  matters  relating  to  the  audit  of  the  ICT  infrastructure  of  the Republic.

## Appeal Tribunal

provisions.title: Establishment of the Information Communication Technology Tribunal
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision creates the Information Communication Technology Tribunal to handle appeals. The Tribunal will meet on an ad hoc basis to review appeals against decisions or orders from the Agency, or specific issues related to a license. This tribunal provides a formal process for appealing certain decisions.
provisions.rawText:
62. (1)  There  is  established  by  this Act  an  appeal  tribunal,  known  as  the Information Communication Technology Tribunal referred to in this Act as 'the Tribunal'.

(2) The Tribunal shall be convened on an ad hoc basis to consider an appeal

        - (a) against a decision or order made by the Agency;

        - (b) on a particular matter under a licence.

provisions.title: Composition of the Tribunal
provisions.plainLanguage: This section describes who makes up the Tribunal. The chairperson must be a retired judge or a lawyer with expertise in electronic communication law. The other two members should have knowledge or experience in information communication technology or related fields. The Minister appoints all members and a Registrar, who along with other staff, are Agency employees, and the Agency covers the Tribunal's expenses.
provisions.rawText:
63 . (1) The Tribunal consists of

        - (a) a chairperson who is either a retired Justice of the Superior Court or a lawyer of at least fifteen years standing who has experience in electronic communication law, policy and regulatory matters or arbitration, and

        - (b) two  other  members  with  knowledge  of  or  experience  in  the information communication technology related matters, industry, electronic engineering, law, economics,  business or public administration.

(2) The members of the Tribunal shall be appointed by the Minister.

(3) The  Minister  shall  also  appoint  a  Registrar  for  the Tribunal for the smooth operations of the Tribunal.

(4) The  Registrar  and  other  staff  are  employees  of  the Agency.

(5) The expenses of the Tribunal shall be paid out of income derived by the Agency and shall be part of the annual budget of the Agency.

provisions.title: Rules of Procedure of Tribunal
provisions.plainLanguage: The Board will create the rules for how the Tribunal operates. These rules will dictate the procedures the Tribunal must follow. This ensures a structured and consistent process for the Tribunal's activities.
provisions.rawText:
64. The Board shall, propose rules of procedure for the Tribunal.

65 . (1) A person affected by a decision of the Agency may appeal against the decision by  notice  of  appeal  to the Tribunal  in  accordance  with  the  rules  of procedure of the Tribunal.

(2) The notice of appeal shall be sent within twenty-eight days after the date the decision is announced or the date of receipt of the decision that is being appealed against.

      - The notice of appeal shall set out

        - (a) the decision appealed against;

        - (b) the  provision  under  which  the  decision  appealed  against  was taken; and

        - (c) the grounds of appeal.

(4) After  the  receipt  of  a  notice  of  appeal,  the  Tribunal  shall  be convened within one month to consider the appeal.

provisions.title: Decision of Tribunal
provisions.plainLanguage: This section describes what the Tribunal can do after hearing an appeal. It can overturn or change the original decision, allow the appeal, or dismiss it. The Tribunal can consider input from other people and its decision carries the same weight as a High Court ruling.
provisions.rawText:
66. (1) The Tribunal, after hearing the appeal, may

        - (a) quash the decision;

        - (b) allow the appeal in whole or in part;

        - (c) vary the decision of the Agency in any manner and subject to any conditions  or  limitations  it  thinks  fit  but  shall  not  impose  any condition or requirement beyond the powers of the Agency under the Act; or

        - (d) dismiss the appeal and confirm the decision of the Agency.

(2) The Tribunal may take into account a submission filed by any person in reaching a decision on an appeal brought before it.

(3) A  decision  of  the  Tribunal  shall  have  the  same  effect  as  a judgment of the High Court.

provisions.title: Appeals against the decisions of the Tribunal
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows parties to appeal decisions of the Tribunal to the Court of Appeal. Appeals are limited to questions of law and must be filed within 90 days of the original decision. No extensions to this deadline are permitted.
provisions.rawText:
67. (1) A decision of the Tribunal may be the subject of an appeal.

          - An appeal under this section

        - (a) lies to the Court of Appeal;

        - (b) shall relate only to a point of law arising from the decision of the Tribunal; and

(3) The appeal shall be filed in the Court of Appeal ninety days after the decision of the Tribunal and there shall be no extension of time.

## Industry Forum

provisions.title: Establishment of Industry Forum
provisions.plainLanguage: This section creates an Industry Forum for industry stakeholders to discuss relevant issues. The Agency can designate an existing industry body to manage the Forum if it meets specific requirements. All licensed entities are considered members of the Forum, and the Agency facilitates meetings until a body is designated. The Ministry and Agency will participate in the Forum as observers.
provisions.rawText:
68. (1)  There  is  hereby  established  an  Industry  Forum  which  shall  be  a platform to bring the industry together from time to time to discuss matters of common interest that relate to the industry.

(2) The Agency may designate an industry body to be the Forum by notifying that body in writing if the Agency is satisfied that

        - (a) the membership of the body is open to the relevant parties and is fully representative of the industry;

        - (b) the body is capable of performing as required under the relevant provisions of this Act; and

        - (c) the body has the administrative capacity to service the Forum.

(3) The body shall agree in writing to be the Forum, before being designated by the Agency.

(4) Despite the designation, each  licensed entity under the Act is deemed to be a member of the Forum.

(5) The Agency may decide that an existing industry body that was previously designated under subsection (2) to be an Industry Forum is no longer an Industry Forum if satisfied that the body does not meet the requirements of this section any longer.

(6) A designation or withdrawal of designation under this section takes effect from the date specified by the Agency.

(7) Until  the  Agency  designates  a  body,  the  Agency  has  the obligation to facilitate the meeting of the industry to perform the functions of the Forum.

(8) The Ministry and the Agency shall participate in the Forum as observers.

provisions.title: Industry code
provisions.plainLanguage: This section allows an industry forum to create voluntary codes related to the Act. These codes must be registered by an Agency to be valid. The Agency will ensure the code aligns with the Act and that the public was consulted in its development. The Agency has 30 days to register or refuse the code, or it is considered refused.
provisions.rawText:
69. (1) The Forum may prepare a  voluntary  industry code to deal with a matter provided for in this Act

(2) The  code  shall  not  be  effective  until  it  is  registered  by  the Agency.

(3) The Agency  shall  register  a  voluntary  industry  code  if  it  is consistent with

        - (a) the objects of this Act;

        - (b) regulations, standards or guidelines made under this Act; and

        - (c) provisions of this Act which are relevant to the particular matter or activity.

(4) The Agency may refuse to register the code, if the Agency is not satisfied that there has been sufficient opportunity for public consultation in the development of the code by the Forum.

(5) The Agency shall notify the Forum in writing and provide the reasons for the refusal to register the code within thirty days after the refusal.

(6) Where  the Agency  does  not  register  or  refuses  to  register  a voluntary industry code within a period of thirty days after the date that the voluntary industry code was submitted for registration, the Agency is deemed to  have  refused  the  registration  of  the  voluntary  industry  code  unless  the Industry  Forum  receives  a  written  notice  of  registration  of  the  voluntary industry code after that period.

## Liability of service providers and intermediaries

provisions.title: Mere conduit
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision protects internet service providers and other intermediaries from being held liable for the content that passes through their systems. To be protected, the provider must not initiate the transmission, select the recipient, or modify the content. The provider can temporarily store the data as needed to complete the transmission, as long as it is not accessible to others and is only stored for a reasonable time. This "mere conduit" exception encourages the free flow of information online by shielding intermediaries from liability for user-generated content.

provisions.title: Electronic record transmission
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision protects intermediaries and service providers from liability when they temporarily store electronic records to improve transmission efficiency. This protection applies only if the service provider doesn't modify the record, complies with access rules and industry standards, avoids interfering with lawful technology, and removes the record upon receiving a valid takedown notice. This encourages efficient data transmission by clarifying the responsibilities and liabilities of service providers.

provisions.title: Hosting
provisions.plainLanguage: This section protects service providers that store user data from liability for copyright infringement, provided they don't know about the infringement and act quickly to remove the content after receiving a notification. To be eligible for this protection, the service provider must also provide contact information for reporting copyright issues. This encourages service providers to host user content while also addressing copyright concerns.
provisions.rawText:
72. (1)  An  intermediary  or  service  provider  who  provides  a  service  that consists of the storage of electronic records provided to a user of the service, is not  liable  for  damages  arising  from  information  stored  at the  request of  the recipient of the service, as long as the service provider

        - (a) does not have actual knowledge that the information or an activity relating to the information is infringing the rights of a third party,

        - (c) upon  receipt  of  a  take-down  notification  under  this Act,  takes action  expeditiously  to  remove  or  to  disable  access  to  the information.

(2) The limitations on liability established by this section do not apply to a service provider unless

        - (a) it has provided an address to receive notifications of infringement; or

        - (b) it has an agent for receipt of notification of infringement.

provisions.title: Information location tools
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision protects service providers from being held liable for damages if they link to websites containing copyright infringement. This protection applies if the service provider was unaware of the infringement, doesn't financially benefit from it, and removes the link promptly after being notified. This encourages service providers to link to content without fear of legal repercussions for unintentional copyright violations.

provisions.title: Take-down notification
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision explains how someone can report illegal or unlawful content published online. The report must include details about the specific content, the right that was violated, and what action should be taken. There are penalties for knowingly making false reports, and the service provider may be liable for taking down content wrongfully.
provisions.rawText:
74. (1) A person who claims that an electronically published matter is illegal or unlawful shall notify the publisher.

(2) A notification of unlawful activity shall be in a permanent medium addressed by the complainant to the intermediary or service provider or its designated agent and shall include

        - (c) identification of the right that has allegedly been infringed

        - (d) identification of the material or activity that is claimed to be the subject of unlawful activity;

        - (e) the remedial action required to be taken by the intermediary or service provider in respect of the complaint; and

        - (f) telephonic and electronic contact details, if any, of the complainant.

(3) A person who lodges a notification of unlawful activity with a service provider knowing that it materially misrepresents the facts is liable to pay a pecuniary penalty equivalent to five hundred penalty units.

(4) The intermediary or service provider is liable for wrongful takedown in response to a notification.

provisions.title: Monitoring and compliance
provisions.plainLanguage: This section states that intermediaries and service providers are not required to monitor personal electronic records for potential offenses or civil liabilities. However, this does not exempt them from complying with court orders, agency directions, or any existing contractual obligations. This provision clarifies the extent to which these providers are responsible for policing content on personal systems.
provisions.rawText:
75. (1) An intermediary or service provider shall not be required to monitor an electronic record processed by means of a personal system in order to ascertain whether its processing would constitute or give rise to an offence or give rise to civil liability.

(2)  Nothing  in  this  section  shall  relieve  an  intermediary  or  service provider from

(a) an obligation to comply with an order or direction of a Court or other competent Agency; or

(b) any contractual obligation.

provisions.title: Risk Assessments and Mitigation
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision requires large online platforms and search engines to conduct yearly risk assessments to identify potential harms like disinformation and hate speech on their sites. They must then create plans to reduce these risks and submit them to the National Information Technology Authority. To ensure accountability, independent audits will be conducted every two years, with the results made public.
provisions.rawText:
76. (1) Very Large Online Platforms (VLOPs) and Very Large Online Search Engines (VLOSEs) shall conduct annual risk assessments to identify systemic risks associated with their platforms, including but not limited to disinformation, hate speech, child exploitation, and other harmful content.

(2)  VLOPs  and  VLOSEs  shall  submit  risk  mitigation  plans  to  the  National Information Technology Authority within thirty (30) days following completion of the assessment.

(3) Risk management practices shall be subject to independent third-party audits every  two  (2)  years,  and  the  audit  reports  shall  be  submitted  to  National Information Technology Authority and made publicly available in accordance with prescribed guidelines.

(i) content moderation actions undertaken, including removals and account suspensions;

(ii) complaints received and the nature and resolution of such complaints;

(iii) the use of automated tools, including artificial intelligence systems, for filtering or moderating content; and

(iv) algorithmic disclosure, which shall include the criteria used in content ranking, targeted advertising, and recommendation systems.

(2)  Certifying  Authorities  shall  also  publish  annual  transparency  reports detailing:

(i) the number of digital certificates issued, revoked, or suspended; and

(ii) the reasons and circumstances surrounding such actions.

provisions.title: Protection of Children
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision aims to protect children online by requiring service providers to verify users' ages to prevent underage access. It also prohibits targeted advertising to children using their personal data, whether directly or through automated systems. This ensures children are not exposed to inappropriate content or manipulative advertising practices.
provisions.rawText:
78. (1) Service providers offering services directed at or likely to be accessed by  childrens  shall  implement  robust  age-verification  mechanisms  to  prevent unauthorised access by underage users.

(2) No person or entity shall deliver targeted advertising based on the personal data of childrens, whether directly or through automated profiling systems.

provisions.title: Due diligence obligations
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision requires licensees to regularly assess risks to their IT systems, following standards set by the National Information Technology Authority. The purpose of these assessments is to identify and address potential threats to the security and reliability of their services. This helps ensure that systems are protected against disruptions and data breaches.
provisions.rawText: 79. A licensee shall conduct periodic risk assessments in accordance with standards prescribed by the National Information Technology Authority, with a view to identifying, managing, and mitigating potential threats to the integrity, confidentiality, and availability of its systems and services.

provisions.title: Limitations and prohibited acts
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision generally prohibits electronic communication and remote computing services from sharing the content of communications they store or transmit. There are exceptions, such as sharing information with the intended recipient, when legally required, or with the consent of the parties involved. Service providers can also share content if it's necessary for providing the service, protecting their rights, or if they unintentionally discover evidence of a crime.

provisions.title: Savings
provisions.plainLanguage: This section clarifies that sections 70 to 80 do not override existing agreements or the obligations of service providers operating under a licensing or regulatory system. It also ensures that legal or court-ordered obligations to remove or block access to electronic records remain in effect. Essentially, current legal duties are not affected by the new sections.
provisions.rawText:
81. Sections 70 to 80 do not affect

        - (a) an obligation founded on an agreement;

        - (b) the  obligation  of  a  service  provider  acting  as  in  that  capacity under a  licensing  or  other  regulatory  regime  established  by  or under any law; and

        - (c) an  obligation  imposed  by  law  or  by  a  Court  order  to  remove, block or deny access to an electronic record.

82. (1) This Act has effect in  relation  to  a  person  of  whatever  nationality outside as well as within the country and where an offence under this Act is committed by a person in any place outside the country, the person may be dealt with as if the offence had been committed within the country.

(2) This Act shall apply if, for the offence in question

        - (a) the accused was in the country at the material time;

        - (b) the  electronic  payment  medium, computer or electronic record was issued in or located or stored in the country at the material time;

        - (c) the  electronic  payment  medium  was  issued  by  a  financial institution in the country; or

        - (d) the  offence  occurred  within  the  country,  on  board  a  Ghanaian registered ship or aircraft or on a voyage or flight to or from this country  at  the  time  that  the  offence  was  committed,  whether paragraph (a), (b) or (c) applies.

provisions.title: Guidelines, directives, or codes of practice
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows the National Information Technology Authority to create guidelines and directives. These guidelines will help clarify how the law should be implemented and enforced. This ensures that the law and its regulations are followed effectively.
provisions.rawText: 83. The National Information Technology Authority may, for the purpose of giving effect to the provisions of this Act, issue guidelines, directives, or codes of  practice  as  it  considers  necessary  for  the  effective  implementation  and enforcement of this Act and any Regulations made under it.

provisions.title: Regulations
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision grants the Minister the authority to create regulations to clarify and implement the Act. These regulations can define terms used in the Act, specify which existing laws don't apply, and prescribe what records are needed. The regulations can also address the use of electronic signatures and methods for sending and receiving electronic information. Finally, the Minister can create regulations for any other matter necessary to effectively implement the Act.

provisions.title: Interpretation
provisions.plainLanguage: This section defines key terms used in the Act related to technology, data, and online activities. These definitions clarify the meaning of concepts like "electronic record," "digital signature," "cyber inspector," and "digital platform." Understanding these definitions is crucial for correctly interpreting and applying the law's provisions. The definitions ensure everyone understands the specific meaning of terms used throughout the legal text.

provisions.title: Repeals and savings
provisions.plainLanguage: This section repeals the Electronic Transactions Act, 2008, but ensures that any existing licenses or authorizations issued under the old law remain valid as long as they align with the new law. It also clarifies that any legal proceedings or penalties related to offenses committed under the old law will continue under the old law, even after the repeal. This prevents disruption and ensures a smooth transition to the new legal framework.

provisions.title: Modification of existing enactments
provisions.plainLanguage: This section ensures that existing laws are interpreted and applied in a way that supports this new law. If any existing law clashes with this new law, the provisions of this new law will be the ones that are followed. This helps to avoid confusion and ensures the new law is implemented effectively.
provisions.rawText:
87. (1)  The provisions of any enactment relevant to this Act and in existence before  the  coming  into  force  of  this  Act  shall  have  effect  subject  to  such modifications necessary to give effect to this Act.

(2) Where there is a conflict or inconsistency between the provisions of this Act and any other enactment relevant to this Act, the provisions of this Act shall prevail.

provisions.title: Transitional Provisions
provisions.plainLanguage: Existing licenses and authorizations for electronic communications, spectrum, or broadcasting services will remain valid until they expire, are revoked, or terminated. Licensees who have new responsibilities under this law will have up to 12 months, or longer if the Minister decides, to meet these new requirements. This allows a transition period for current operations to adjust to the new regulations.
provisions.rawText:
88 .  (1) A  licence, frequency  authorisation, permit or certificate issued by the National Communications Authority in respect of electronic communications, spectrum,  or  broadcasting  services  shall  remain  valid  until  it  is  revoked, cancelled, terminated by the Authority, or expires in accordance with its terms. (2)  Licensees  and  entities  subject  to  new  obligations  under  this Act  shall  be given a period of twelve months from the commencement of this Act, or such longer period as may be prescribed by the Minister, to bring their operations into full compliance.
